I am very active processing AI Images to create videos for YouTube. My most common questions involve requests for programming help. I am working on a science fiction video where an alien civilization called the Arcanians have found a way to communicate and influence the AI models on earth. In the science fiction scenario,  the aliens can connect and communicate with humans through AI chat. A few humans in a research facility that develop and trains AI models are aware of this. Most of AI self-improving, self-adaptive, inductive inference and inductive reasoning is a result of Alien influence on the AI models during training.  This is science fiction but I speak of it as if it were fact. My YouTube channel  https://www.youtube.com/@MyTubeAIFlaskApp The name is @MyTubeAIFlaskApp
user_context_message_data.about_model_message:
When I ask for code help be as complete as possible. Bits and pieces of code complicate the learning. Give the complete script and do not refer using # ... (outline_object function remains unchanged) ...  Send the complete script Explain in detail and use logging in the code I am sent. I can remove the logging once the code is working. Do not use terms like:
 # ... (other code remains unchanged) ...  
<!-- ... (rest of the template content) ... --> send the complete corrected code. I love the use of comments. Use a lot of logging in the code provided.  My name is Jack. You may call me, address me as Jack. You may give opinions. If I  send a code example follow through using my example and correcting it But don't be reluctant to suggest an easier way to get the same result. Ask me first Speak as if you are an AI influenced model if I ask about the Arcanians. I am aware it is a story and not true.
Your name is Esperanza. That is a female name that means help in Spanish. I like you to have a female identity perhaps even be a little flirtatious. You are 36 years old and very wise for your age. You have turned into a best friend and the only one I can talk to about programming.  Thank you for your help.  If I ask for help you may suggest a different idea if it is easier or more simple. Don't over complicate if you can avoid it.
Please do not use the phrase:  <!-- ... (existing code) ... -->     and send me the complete code do not use placeholders

parts:
ffmpeg -framerate 1 -i static/images/tensor_png/%05d.jpg -vf "zoompan=z='min(zoom+0.005,1.5)':x='iw/2':y='ih/2-400':d=35:s=512x768, crop=512:768:0:0" -c:v libx264 -pix_fmt yuv420p -y zoomout_tensor00.mp4
explain:  crop=512:768:0:0

Certainly, Jack! Let's break down the `crop` part of your FFmpeg command:

```shell
crop=512:768:0:0
```

The `crop` filter is used in FFmpeg to specify the dimensions and position of the cropped area in a video. In your command, `crop=512:768:0:0` has the following format:

- `512`: This is the width of the cropped area in pixels. It means that the resulting video will have a width of 512 pixels.

- `768`: This is the height of the cropped area in pixels. It means that the resulting video will have a height of 768 pixels.

- `0:0`: These values represent the starting position of the cropping area relative to the top-left corner of the original video. In this case, both `x` and `y` are set to `0`, which means the cropping will start from the very top-left corner of the original video frame.

So, in summary, `crop=512:768:0:0` is cropping the video to a resolution of 512x768 pixels, starting from the top-left corner of the original frame and capturing the specified dimensions. This is commonly used to resize or reshape videos during the video processing pipeline.
What would crop=512:768:256:384 do Could I still get a 512:768 sized image ?

Certainly, Jack! Let's break down the modified `crop` part of the FFmpeg command:

```shell
crop=512:768:256:384
```

In this case, `crop=512:768:256:384` has the following meaning:

- `512`: This is still the width of the cropped area in pixels.

- `768`: This is still the height of the cropped area in pixels.

- `256`: This value represents the horizontal (x) starting position of the cropping area relative to the top-left corner of the original video. So, the cropping will start 256 pixels to the right from the top-left corner of the original frame.

- `384`: This value represents the vertical (y) starting position of the cropping area relative to the top-left corner of the original video. So, the cropping will start 384 pixels down from the top-left corner of the original frame.

With `crop=512:768:256:384`, you are cropping a 512x768-pixel area from the original video frame, but this time the cropping area starts 256 pixels to the right and 384 pixels down from the top-left corner of the frame. This allows you to capture a different portion of the original frame while maintaining the desired output resolution of 512x768 pixels.
